title: B5084.pdf
content:
sorb 
food. Anything that we eat and drink must be broken down into 
smaller molecules of nutrients before they can be absorbed into the blood and 
carried to cells throughout the body. Digestion is the process by which food and 
drink are broken down into tiny particles so that the body can use them to build, 
nourish cells and provide energy. It involves mixing food with digestive juices, moving it through the digestive tract, and breaking down large molecules of food into smaller molecules. This process begins in the mouth, when we chew and 
swallow and is completed in the small intestine. Thoroughly chewing the foods 
aids the digestion process.
Organs that make up the digestive tract are the mouth, esophagus, stomach, 
small intestine, large intestine - also called the colon - rectum, and anus. Digestive 
juices are produced in the mouth, stomach, and small intestine to help digest food.
